div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,547] ALEXANDRIA, TUESDAY, JULY 17, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until 4 June, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. Combined fare to London by sea and train de luxe via Brindisi or via Maresilles £194.11.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: The Engish Daily Newspaper, Established 1886
Editor and Manager - - R. SMELLING
ONE PLASTRE TARIFF
Tuesday, July 17, 1906.
AN EGYPTIAN AMALGAMATION

It appears that the amalgamation of the Egyptian Land and General Trait, limited, with the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Limited, is, the "Financial Times" says, not to be amplitude so smoothly and easily as seemed likely at the start It will be remembered that the proposal wu that the shareholders of the former Company should exchange their shay for those of the latter Company, giving six for one. The agreement was signed subject to the approval of the shareholders in general meeting^and the Directors of both Companies recommended their shareholders to give such approval It is interesting to note in the light of subsequent events that the Egyptian land and General Trust's oironlar farther stated that a very general desire had been expressed by a large body of shareholders to carry oat the proposed amalgamation. Both Companiesoalled meetings for the 19th inly for the purpose of ratifying the agreement, and the Egyptian Delta Lard and Investment Company took the opportunity to seek for powers to raise its nominal capital from £250,000 to £500,000 and make soma minor alterations in its articles of association. This was how the matter stood until the shareholders of the Egyptian Land and General Trust received an extraordinary oironlar, in which the attention of the shareholders is called to the proposal of the Delta Company to increase its capital, and they are. told " Your Directors have not been advised when or at what price it is contemplated to make the new issue, bat it is obvious that the apparent imminence of so large an issue of new shares mast prevent the vain of the shares bearing the proportion which existed at the date of the provisional contract to the assets of the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Limited, already acquired." The Directors on aoooont of what appears to be an imaginary change in the condition say that they can no longer take the responsibility of recommending the confirmation of the agreement When we read this oironlar (says one confrère) we were at a loss to understand how the difficulty could have arisen. The statement lint the Directors au the Trust Company had no knowledge of the time when and the terms upon which the Delta Company proposed to issue the new Bare could suggest no less to ns than that the Boards of the two Companies had come to loggerheads over the aftermath of this negotiations and could no longer disease since a simple matter. Upon inquiry, however, w learn that the Delta Company knew nothing whatever of the Trust Company's objection to the increase of capital until the Eire lar from wbiob we have quoted bad beec posted. This makes the oiroular utterly in comprehensible. It most be remembered that the agreement had been signed subject to the ratification of the shareholders on the 19th, and that the Delta Company would not obtain authority for the increase of its capital until that day, so that it would be impossible for the new shares to be issued before the shareholders of the Trust Company had become shareholders of the Delta Company. In any pro rata issue after that they would have an opportunity of subscribing their quota and rr training their proportionate interest ia the assets of the Company. If, therefore, the Trust Company's Directors had obtained an under taking from the Delta Company that the new shares would only be issued to the shareholders in proportion to they're holding there would not have been the slightest ground for any orange in their attitude towards the amalgamation. We have little doubt that this or some other satisfactory undertaking would have been given by the Delta Company had request been made for it, as there is nothing what-, ever in the whole transaction to suggest that any unfair advantage was to be taken of the Trust Company's shareholders. The circular of the latter Company distinctly, though in-directly, indicates that there is some ground f )r objecting to the action of the Directors of the Delta Company, but they did not attempt to get the matter cleared up. It appears, indeed, that for some inexplicable reason the Directors of the Egyptian Land and General Trust Company having made a bargain regretted it The agreement provided that the two Companies should continue to conduit their own business until completion, and that the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company should lend to the Trust Company not exceeding £57,000 to enable the latter Company to meet payments falling due on lands already purchased. It would seem probable, therefore, that this money, or some of it, has bear advanced, and that it is after being relieved of their financial embarrassments that the Directors of the Trust Company see fresh light on the subject. Had they sought to have the difficulties removed before approaching their shareholders, it would be possible to understand their change of attitude, but their failure to do so suggests that they were anxious not to be oonviooed.

div.head: Cattle Plague.
div.p: It has been decided to include the districts of Tantah (Qharbit hi and Nawa (Kalionbieb) among those infected with cattle plague.

div.head: Military School.
div.p: The Ministry of War has transferred 18 cadets of the Military School to the Egyptian Army and raised them to the rank of'Molazim Toni.

div.head: The Cost of Denishwai.
div.p: The Ministry of Finance has opened a credit cf LB. 19,000 to meet the expenses ol the Special Court and the pay of the employés who were engaged in the Denishwai case.

div.head: Murdered by Robbers.
div.p: Our Eeneh Correspondent telegraphs that the Sanaf of Blab Markaz. Dechna, on returning home yesterday evening, was reordered by a band of robbers. An enquiry into the case is going on.

div.head: Embezzling Government Money.
div.p: A council of discipline held at the Ministry of War, Cairo, has dismissed Mohamed Off. Fuad, employé in the Army Stores Department, for stealing a snm of money belonging to the Government.

div.head: San Stefano Casino.
div.p: The inauguration of the Casino theatre will take place on Saturday next with a variety company. Season tickets may be had for boxes and stalls. On and after Sunday next there will be a matinée from 6 to 7 p.m.

div.head: Temporary Police School.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has let the residence of Aly Pasha Cherif, at Sbaria Abdul Aziz, Cairo, with a view to converting it into a school for the police cadets, and making nse of it till the new Police School building at Abbacies has been finished.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Daring the week ending the 15th inst. four cases of plague were reported, all at Alexandria. From January 1 to July 15 there were 880 oases of plagae in Egypt, against 158 in 1905 and 716 in 1901, daring the corresponding periods of the two latter years.

div.head: Horse Kills Robber.
div.p: A curious occurrence is reported by our Damanhonr Correspondent. On Saturday night a man forced his way into the yard or a resident of Tod with the object of stealing his horse. While in the sot of undoing the rope which wee tied to the horse's leg the animal Ïtve the man a kick in the face, which killed im on the spot.

div.head: Ministry of Public Instruction.
div.p: The special eoonoil of the Ministry of Fnblio Instruction, after examination of the decision of the cannel of discipline dismissing Cb. Arafa Aly Ghorab, Bnb-inspeotor in the Ministry, resident at Chitin el Kom, for uttering untrntha in connection with facts relative to his fnnotions, has decided to reverse this judgment and to retrograde Afar Aly Ghorah from his class, which is from L.E. 16 to L.B. 30, and to redone him to the rank of simple teaser, while allowing him his present salary of L.B. 16 a month, corresponding to the maximum of the L E. 19 to L.B. 16 class.

div.head: GERMAN COMPETITION.
THE CAUSE OF ITS SUCCESS.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir,—Fending the examination promised by the "Chsmber of Commeroe Journal" for next month's issue, might I anticipate that enquiry by giving an opinion in which I believe 1 am supported by a general oonsensna i To explain the canse of the success of Qerman competition in Egypt and elsewhere one need only sum it up in two words : German adaptability.

Why Qerman goods are making suoh inroads every where — in 12 years, vide the "Chamber of Commeroe Journal," they rose fromi 2.5 % to 4.4 %—is not because of their superior' quality, nor of their oheaper prices ; bat be-canse, like the American, the Qerman manufacturer, following the advioe of his agent, goes ont of the way, often at a sacrifice, to suit and so win the foreign market Our polioy is to soit onrselve* ; to ram ont patterns and prices down the customer's throat. No doubt our goods are better made, and there is a majority who .requite willing to pay for the British finish. WW they objeot to is the British pattern—as immutable as the laws ol the Meaes and Persians. When, however, their objeotion is mildly conveyed by the agent to the home manufacturer, what is the result 1 I will tell yon. Some years ago a British agent urged his firm to imitate a particular shape of spade. What was the reply! "We manufacture only one shape of spade ; they oan either like it or lump it." And this is oharacteristio of the attitude of the Trade Union.
The result is, as the plain faots and figures ol the Alexandria Chamber of Commerce how, that the Qerman steps in, matches the looal article at a oheaper prioe, and takes away our custom.

The other potent asset in the Qerman hands is oredit. Onr terms are prompt cash, oasb against doouments, or e.o.d. If the natives won't pay, we don't cars, for we can always send our good j ont to the Colonies.
The German obliges ; the Englishman compels. That is thé reason of Germany's snooess. YonrB, eto., Xenos.
P.S.—I am not a Little Englander, nor do I uphold Mr. Dillon. I stiok simply to positive figure and fact ; which is the dnty of practioal Englishman to do. X.

div.head: GERMANY AND ISLAM.
AN EXPEDITION TO SAHARA TRIBES
div.p: The "Eoho de Paris" learns from its Rome correspondent that an important German ex petition is to study the caravan route in the hinterland of Tripoli.

The expedition, which will be commanded by a German iffier, has been organized oy Baron Oppenheim with the object of getting into friendly oommnoioation with the Ssnonssi and the Mussulman population, and of gaining over the Sheikhs to German influence.

According to a Dalziel'e message from Rome, a correspondent of the "Vita" says that the German Mission is already touring in the hinterland of Tripoli, and adds that Baron Oppenheim prepared the visit of the German Emperor to Tangier and was the agent of Count Tattenbaoh in Egypt.

This expedition has been talked about before, and may bave some connection with another one of fifty or sixty soldiers and officers which the Sultan of Turkey has ordered to be made to Kanem, a territory North of Lake Chad. He also announced his intention of ooonpying the town of Mao in that territory, though Mao is a French possession.

div.head: A MODEL NEWSPAPER.
LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL'S VENTURE.
div.p: The following is a translation ofClanse 3 of the rules which have been laid down for the conduct of the newspaper which is to be published shortly by the Legislative Connoil in Cairo :—

"The paper is to be entirely Egyptian ; its tank is to defend and work for the advantage of Egypt, to guide and lead the whole nation to prosperity, to publish all that will be deemed proper and useful, morally and financially, to criticize every atom that may in any way endanger the entry's was'-being, no matter if that action be general or special, and to state the troth on both sides in order to form a public opinion based on strong principles. The paper's voice will, it is believed, reach the ears of the authorities and merit their oonfidenoo; and both the Government and the Legislative Connoil will go hand in hand to seek the welfare and advantage of the nation, considering no differences between faiths or nationalities, patting aside all personal ends, and dealing with nothing in connection with purely religions affairs.''
We hope our new contemporary will live up to these excellent sentiments.

div.head: STEAMER AGROUND IN CANAL.
div.p: (From our Correspondent)
Suez, Monday.

The S.S. Pathan. bound to Vladivostok, grounded early this morning in the Canal near Kilo. 153, and stopped the traffic for a few hours, until she was safe'y moored, thus leaving a clear passage to the steamers. The vessel is still ashore, and the tug Robots has been sent to how assistance, bat so far all her efforts to reflect her have been unsnooMsfo'. 4t is expected, however, that she will come off at next high tide.

div.head: CAIRO FIRM SWINDLED.
div.p: A few days ago an individual went to a large English shop in Cairo and bought articles to the value of 6 or 7 pounds. When he went to the desk to pay for his pnrohases, however he said that ha bad not saflhient money to settle for all, and asked that the paroel might (be sent to him, with an invoioe, to the Bristol "Hotel. This was done, and the messenger found the stranger in the hall. The latter took him to his room, and there proceeded leisurely to oheok the artioles with the invoice. Finally he asked as to the whereabonts of two waistooats. The me3Benger naturally knew nothing about the waistcoat», for which he was severely scolded, and the iniividual wrote his oomplaint on the book of the invoice and sent him back to fetoh them. The messenger returned to the shop, and after enquiries about the missing artioles, a second messenger was sent. He, however, found that the individual in question had left the hotel with a paroel under his arm, alleging that the wrong parcel bad been sent to him.

It was afterwards ascertainad that the man had gone to the Bristol Hotel and made arrangements for a room. He said that he had left his luggage at the station and gave the hall porter a written order for their delivery to him. It is needless, however, to say that the porter found no luggage at the station. The head of the firm admitted that they had been oleverly tricked by this rascal, and oommnnioated with the police.

div.head: FRONTIER BLUE BOOK
div.p: THE DANGER OF FANATICISM
EGYPT'S REPTILE PRESS.
INCREASE OF BRITISH GARRISON.
London, July 16.

A Bine Book has been published on Th. Tnroo-Egyptian frontier dispute. A despot from Lord Cromer to Sir B. Grey, dated 31a May, referred to the danger of an advance o the Canal. A serions attack on Egypt seems not of the question, bat a possible raid might be attempted with a view to loaning an out burst of fanaticism in Egypt Snob an attempt would have been of a most desperate nature as a reverse would mean the annihilation o the attackers ; bat it Beemed undesirable t take risks, so the Navy undertook to defeat the Canal. /

Dealing with the influence of the Pan-Islamic Press, Lord Cromer doubts as to whether an; newspapers wonld rival its mendacity and mis representation of faots, bat opines that i should be left alone for the present, trusting t time and relianoe on the true fiaota oonvinoini the Egyptian public of the folly of thoa preaching Pan-Islamism. Bat if the Pres seriously menaoes public tranquillity, it wanly be the duty of the Government to resort h repression. Anyhow, this conolnsion may bi drawn abundantly olear, namely, that thi British garrison mast be permanently increase! at the ooat of the Egyptian treasury. (Reuter
THE GARRISON IN EGYPT.

In the House of Commons last week Mr Ashley asked the Secretary of State for Wai if there was any intention to farther redaa the British garrison in Egypt, in view of thi fanatical feeling existing in that entry ant in the North of Africa generally.
Mr. Runoimao (for Mr. Haldane) : Tbi answer is in the negative.

Telegraphing on Monday night, the Malts correspondent of the "Daily Telegraph' says :—So far as oan be ascertained at present there does not appear to be any tonndation to) the statement made by the Alexandria oorres pondent of a London paper that troopi qoartered here have been ordered to hole themselves in readiness to prooeed to Egypt at a moment's notice.
PIGEON-SHOOTING IN EGYPT.
Mr. Haldane, in a written answer to a ques tion by Mr. Dillon, states

"Lord Cromer, in a telegram dated the Htl inst., stated that the order hitherto existing ii Egypt has been that no pigeon-sh oring wai to take plaoe without the oonaent of the Model of the village, and that since the Denishwai incident the general officer commanding it Egypt was about to issue orders forbidding thi shooting of pigeons in the future, bat I an not aware of the terms of the order, or tbs date of its issne."
THE FASHN TRAGEDY.

Various are the vereio.s asoribed to the motives of Ahmed Qomaa, who was lately condemned by the Native Court of Minieh to the extreme penalty for the mnrder, a month ago, at Fashn, in Upper Egypt, of a Greek woman and her nieoe. The sentenoe has not yet been oarried ont, owing to the complete disavowal of Qomaa as to having committed the orime.

Justice has been suspended apparently owing to the foot that an enquiry is being instituted by the Hellenio Consular Conrt of Alexandria against Sotiris Cottai, who is aoonsed of complicity in the orime ; and it is probably owing to some legal adjustment being necessary between the two oonrts oonoerned that this delay has taken place, otherwise the failure of the Native Tribunal to exeonte its sentenoe would appear incomprehensible. Two motives are attributed : one of robbery, for the deoeased woman had in her dwelling the snm of one hundred and odd pounds, oolleoted in rents and from the sale of ootton seed ; the other, outrage committed on the person of her niece, though of this there is no absolute proof.

div.head: NILE STEAMER SERVICE
NEW STEAMERS FOR THE RIVER
div.p: We learn from America that Ur. Osoar Ems, ot New York, has taken the management of the Express Nile Steamship Company.
The company'a new steamers will be lannohed this sommer, and are modern river craft.

The Express Nile steamer fleet will be ready next December, and we are assured that tourists will find that the new express steamers oan compare with the newe-t and finest river steamers in the world. On board the new steamers there will be found spaoious glassed 'observation room, telephone, eleotrio bells, eleotrio fans and steam beat A restaurant à la oarte will be found on the rapid steamers, which Will make the run between Luxor and Assouan (133 miles) in twelve hours. These steamers will run in connection with the train de luxe of the International Sleeping Car Company. A good number of passengzrs have already been booked for the next winter's reason.

Among the passengers already booked for the opening season are : Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Haines, of Burlington, N. J. ; Mrs. Hattie De Lesoaille and daughter, of Davenport, Iowa ; Mr. and Mrs. George E. Barstow, of Baratow, Tex. ; Rev. and Mrs. Henry Marsh Warren, of New York; Mr. and Mrs. William T. Purdy, of New York ; Rev. John T. MoAtee, of Philadelphia ; Mr. and Mrs. W.H. Warner, ot Cleveland, Ohio, and Mr. H. C. Franois, of Fnila-delphia. These passengers are lesving by Mr. Clark's specially chartered steamer Arabio next February.

div.head: EGYPTIAN GOLD AND GEM SYNDICATE
DISPUTED MINING RIGHTS.
div.p: In the Chancery Division last week, before Mr. Jostioe Neville, Mr. Edwin William Streeter, a jeweller, sued the Egyptian Gold and Gem Syndicate, Limited, claiming a declaration that the defendants' rights' under an agreement of Maroh 19, 1903, had lapsed, and that they had no right or title to a certain concession or prospeoting lioense specified in the agreement.

Mr. Spence, in opening the case, said Mr. Streeter obtained a concession from the Egyptian Government, which authorised the plaintiff for a term of thirty years to take preoions stones and sell them in a particular distriot described in the oonoession. One tenth of the profits made on the work-ng of the eenoern was to be paid to the Egyptian Government.

There was to be a rental of £305. Mr. Streeter entered into an agreement with a Mr. Oxley in January, 1903, by which Mr. Oxley was to purchase the entire oonoession. Before that time Mr. Streeter applied to the Egyptian Government for a prospeoting license. The mining oonoession was merely for precious stones, and did not give the right to the gold or minerals. The prospecting lioense was for three years. The holder was not allowed to keep any preoious metals, but was allowed to see whether there was gold. It was not granted at the time of the agreement to Oxley, but it was granted in April, 1903. It was to last for three years ; the rent for ths first year was to be £1,030. and the term was to expire in April, 1906. Mr. Oxley was to promote a ■vndinate for the acnoisition of the nronartv. and plaintiff was to receive £7,003 and a number of folly paid up ahares on the exeroise of the option. The option was exercised in September, 1904 The shares had never been issued to the plaintiff, nor had he been paid money.
The hearing was adjourned.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARES IN LONDON.
div.p: Messrs. Reid and Barnard, of Cairo and Alexandria, have opened a branoh office in London at 9, Threadneedle-street. In this connection a London contemporary remarks t

A sign of the times is the fact that several Egyptian firms of stockbrokers are about to commence business in London. Hitherto the market for Egyptian shares, except in the oase of a few specialities, has been a very limited one in this country. The faot that a number of important Cairo firms oonsider it good business to bave branch establishments over here seems to indioate that an attempt is to be made to broaden this interest. Certainly the reoent history of several Egyptian enterprises gives oolour to the idea that our Cairo friends bave kept the good things to themselves, and have given ns the benefit of ventures like the Nile Valley Company. This time it has been a oase of "spoiling the Britishers."

div.head: THE NILE FLOOD.
div.p: ESTIMATE OF PROBABLE RISE.

The following Memorandum by Capt. H. G. Lyons, Director General of the Survey Department, on the meteorological conditions in Egypt anfl the 8udan, with an estimate of the probable rise of the Nile flood, has just been issued :— '

In the foreoast issued at the beginning of May it was pointed out that although heavy rains in Abyssinia and the southern Sudan had fallen in February and again in Maroh, their effect should not be confused with that of the early advanoing rains of the summer monsun.

These early and abnormal rains raised the level of the Blue Nile considerably and thus converted what would have been s very low summer supply into a fairly good one as may be seen from the reading of the Wady Haifa gauge (in metres):
Date March April May June
1— 5 —0.55 —0.95 —0.06 —0.28
6—10 —0.55 —0.29 —0.12 —0.84
11—15 —0.56 —0.25 —0.19 —0.45
16—20 —0.48 —0.20 —0.26 —0.43
21—25 —0 37 —007 —0 22 —0.43
26—30 —0.24 —0.03 —0.21 —0.60
These also show the rapid fall after the effect of these exceptional rises had passed off.

It was pointed out also in the May foreoast that the meteorological conditions during March and April over the Equatorial portion of Eastern Africa and the neighbouring portion of the Indian Ocean were markedly unfavourable to early or heavy rains in the Nile Basin.
Since then statements have appeared in the public press that a high Nile flood is anticipated so that it is desirable to summarise the data which are available more fully than has usually been done.
Conditions nr Mat.—Rainfall was in excess on the coast near Zanxibar and Mombasa, but in defeot on the platean of British East Africa and on the north of Lake Viotoria.

Rain fell at a few places on the Sudan plains but in small quantities only. On the Bahr el Jebel rainfall was normal or slightly deficient.

Lake and River Levels.

Lake Viotoria was very high in oonse-qnenee of the heavy rains of March, April and May ; the Bahr el Jebel at Gondokoro increased a little ; the Sobat began to rise at Nasser on May 1st, and at Doleib Hilla a few days later, after which it rose steadily. The Jar (Bahr el Ghasal) showed a marked rise at the end of May.
The Blue Nile at Roseires commenced to rise in the middle of the month.
It will be seen from the above that the rains set in somewhat later than the average and were moderate in strengh.

The continnanoe of heavy rain in the equatorial region, Zanzibar, eto., was an unfavourable sign, as also were the unsteadiness of the air movement over the Arabian Sea, and theiUrge"Iw«mulation of snow in the Himalayas which the Meteorological Department of India reports. Atmospherio pressure over North East Africa was in exoess of the normal and this has hitherto been an unfavourable sign.

Conditions in June.—The rainfall during this month was above the average at Zvwbar. It was average at Wan in the Bshr el Gbszal and at Gor d ikoro on the Bahr el Jebel, thongh somewhat deficient at Wsdelai.
On the White Nile rain is never heavy in June and the amounts recorded this year vary considerably, being in exoess at Dueim and deficient at Khartoum.
On the Blue Nile the rainfall was above the average at Roseires and below it at Wad Medani, while at Qallabat and Gedaref it was about normal.

table.head: Rainfall (in mm.) FOR MONTH OF JUNE.

div.p: River Gadqbs—In this month the main interest attaches to the Blue -Nile and the Atbara; the White Nile is unimportant as it will shortly be held baok by the rising Bine Nile flood.

The rise of the Sobut continued steadily throughout the month ; the Blue Nile at Roseires oommeooed a rapid rise on the 16th, which bas oontintmd almost uneheoked to the present date; and affected the Khartoum gauge from the beginning ot July.

The rise of the Sobut continued steadily throughout the month ; the Blue Nile at Roseires oommeooed a rapid rise on the 16th, which bas oontintmd almost uneheoked to the present date; and affected the Khartoum gauge from the beginning ot July.

It should be remembered that the favourable conditions shown by the Roeeiret and Khartoum gauges are partly due to the abnormal rains of February and March, so that the gauge readings tend to make the rainfall of Abyssinia appear heavier than it actually was.
In June and up to July 19 the river rose at Tewfikieh 68 cm. in the AS days, which is a normal rate of rise.

The Blue Nile at Roseires is so rapidly affeoted by successive flood waves from the Abyssinian tableland which cause the water level to rise or fall by as mneh as 1 to 1.5 | metre in 94 hours, that a satiefkotory oom-j parison between snooessive years is dfffienlt.
This year the level bas risen 3.40 metres in ; the above period of 42 days which seems to be little if at all above the average.
At Khartoum the rise which began about May 28th, was unsteady during June, amounting to 1.01 metre, but beoame steady in July,
The level at Wady Haifa only began to rise markedly in July, 0.46 metre in 19 days.

It should be remembered that the favourable conditions shown by the Roeeiret and Khartoum gauges are partly due to the abnormal rains of February and March, so that the gauge readings tend to make the rainfall of Abyssinia appear heavier than it actually was.
In June and up to July 19 the river rose at Tewfikieh 68 cm. in the AS days, which is a normal rate of rise.

The Blue Nile at Roseires is so rapidly affeoted by successive flood waves from the Abyssinian tableland which cause the water level to rise or fall by as mneh as 1 to 1.5 | metre in 94 hours, that a satiefkotory oom-j parison between snooessive years is dfffienlt.
This year the level bas risen 3.40 metres in ; the above period of 42 days which seems to be little if at all above the average.
At Khartoum the rise which began about May 28th, was unsteady during June, amounting to 1.01 metre, but beoame steady in July,
The level at Wady Haifa only began to rise markedly in July, 0.46 metre in 19 days.
It will be seen from the above table that op to the present time the rise of the river level is not above the average rise for this period, though Roseires shows reoent signs of improvement

The amonnt of snow on the Himalayas is reported to have diminished, and the wind in the Arabian Sea was of normal foroe at the end of June, so that at the present time it may be ssid that there has been an improvement and rains from being weak have increased in the Abyssinian area, though they still do not appear to be muoh above the average. In the first half of Joly conditions may be described as fair, but nothing as yet justifies the assumption that the flood will be unusually large. Bains have so far been weak and undecided in most plaoes, though at Roseires and at Kodok they have been somewhat above the average in June, rainfall at Zanzibar on the const of -German Bast Afrioe was still in excess, pointing to a continuation of an ascensional current, and atmospherio pressure has been consistently above the average.

Conditions at present seen^ to point to a moderate and not an exoessive rate of rise of the flcod. It is probable that tha breaks in the Joty and Augnst rains which often ooonr are due to local conditions on the Abyssinian table-land, and information is too scanty from this area as yet, to admit of saoh changea being accurately anticipated, but the general weakness of the monsoon onrreut this year renders them not unlikely unless the recent improvement is maintained.

We regret to announce the death of Liaut.-Col. Germain, of the Frenoh Colonial Artillery, which took plara a few days ago at Paria This gallant and distinguished officer was one of the companions of Major Marchand in the famous expedition to Fashoda, whioh, whatever its political consequenoes, was one of the most remarkable feats ever performed by a military foroe under the most adverse -conditions of distarira and olimata.

div.p: OFFICIAL REPORT.

The following is the text Qf ajreport pnb lished ,by .the Public Health,. Department on the quality of the water famished to the oity of Cairo-:— Les poits de BocLEl Farag ont lté oonstroite dans le hat d'assnrer b 1* ville dn Caire one eaa potable exempte de toot danger de conta ruination. L'eau'-du- Nil filtrée à travers des coaches de sable distribaée jatqn'ioi ne donnait pas cette garantig, paroe que 1»- constrnotion des filtres était défectueuse et lew snrfaœ était de beeuooup drop.restreinte. La nécessité a'im posait dono impérieusement de remédier h oet état de choses Pour œla U y.avait deux possibilités: Hem placer les aaoisns filtres par, ans i natal latioo ds fUtrage-baséa sur les . principes mo denies, on orenser des paits profonds et se servitude 11 eaa de la nappe, souterraine. D'aprin l'opinion unanime. des hygiénistes du monde entier on devait-se déoider poor l ean de.puits si celle-là pouvait être-trouvée de bonne qualité en quantité suffisante. Car non» savons aujourd'hui que l'eau de la happe souterraine profonde dans.un séide la configu- ration géologique de oelnide la -vallée du Nil du Delta est. eu elle-même libre de germes vi- vants et: qu'elle est exempte-de touts oontami nation., provenant de la surface, pourvu-qae les pnits soient bien.construits d'après les règles de llbjrgiène. Un.approviaicnnement en ean de la nappe: sonterraiqaprofonde aurait dono éoartéb jamais la transmission de maladies infectieuses par voiadej'eau potable,.tandis'.qne la système te pins perfectionné de filtrage, de lean du Nil, il estwraifapiftit réduitœ.daoger an minimum, mais n'anrait jamais pn donner ans garantie absalne. 1 Des-sondages lait» sur différents points dans les-eurviruns delà ville du.Caire démontrèrent qrte la nappe -souterraine se trouvant b proxi- mité-deiRod Bt Farag se prêtait le mieux è l'approvisionnement de la. ville tant an point de vaeds la qualité que-de la quantité , de l'ean trouvée Deux pnitp, dont chacun .pouvait fournir _ 4,000 mètres cabes d'eau dans les 24 heures, furent dono construits b des points distants environ aille mètres-l'an de l'antre et pourras d'uneineUUaSion de pompage. Ce» deux puits onttravaülé l'un-pendent trois - ans, l'eotro pendant-plus de-deux ans peetque continuel- lement jeu» et naît, b an débit d'environ 4,000.métrés chacun. Fendant presque deux ans l'eau de ont deux puits a servi b l'alimentation da quartier dr Boulaq : san» que-, la population se sort plainte d*sa qualité. iranalyse chimique de-oette .ean a été faite h différentes reprises pendant les trois -années que-le» pnits eut fonctionné. le ean, était- toujears tent à fait-claire, limpide eteansoouleor Sa température con- stante i était d+23° C. (températare moyenne dol'aaaée au Caire) en été oomme eu hiver. L'examen baotériologiqoe prouvait qa'elle ne oontenait pas de baotéries, sauf quelques rares germes banaux de microbes.aquatiques dont la pallulation inévitable a lieu dans les tuyaux. En comparant .les. analyses chimiques, de l'eau des puits et del'eau .du Nil, -ou voit ^u'il n'y a pas dans la composition de oes deux eaux, de différence très prononcée. Il J»!y a que le degré hydrotimétrique qui est plus élevé pour l'eau die puits. Pendant le temp'B du haut Nil l'eau des puits est environ deux fois et demi plus dore que l'eau du Nil, mais cette différence diminue considérablement pendant le temps de l'étiage, de sorte -que, par exemple, au moi de mai, la différence du degré hydrotimétrique des deux eaux est réduite è la proportion de 7: 5. L'élévation du . degré bydrotimétrique de l'eau- des puits est due h. la présence d'une quantité plus forte de bicatbonats de chaox et de magnésie et non h ans augmentation de Bnlfate de ohsox. Au contraire, l'eau, des puits oontient ordinairement un peu moins d'aoide Bulfuriqge^ue l'eau do-N il* surtout.au temps de. l'étiage.' C'est là Un fait à remarquer quant à l'u- sage de l'eau des puits pour des botsindustriels, paroe que o'est précisément surtout les sulfates deiehaux qui forment les écailles dangereuses dans-les-chaudières à vapeur. L'élévation, du degré hydrotimétrique se tient du reste dans des limites très modérées, de manière que l'eau des poits de Roi El Faragpeut encore être considérée comme one eaa douoè. Eu effet, la pins grande partie des eanx ; utilisées poor l'alimentation publique dans les grandes villes, en Angleterre, en Allemagne et en France, ont le même degré de dureté ou sont enoore plus dures. Une eau n'est considérée généralement oom me réellement date que lorsque le degré hydrothnétriqae dépasse 30 degrés francus. Or l'eau des (toits de Rod El Farg a un degré hydrotimétrique d'environ- -30 degrés françiis. La chaux qui est -esntenu» i dans-l'eau de i puits de Rod El.Fqrag c'y trouvant presque exclusivement sous forme de bioarbonate,-donne à cette eau le goût particulièrement fiais et agréable que nous sommes habitués à apprécier dans les bonnes eanx de sonros. Cela oonstitue un réel avantage v>sà vis de l'eau du Nil qui oontient bcauooup moins d'aoide carbonique. En outre, l'eau des puits oontient ordinal restent moins de sel matin que l'eau du Nil. Pendant le temps de l'étiage, la quantité de sel -trouvée dans l'eatr du Nil est environ deux fois abdeinie fins télevée îque dans J'sau de puits. Du reste, ane- grande partie- des eaux uti- lisées en Europe pour l'alimentation publique ooulfo^ -pl»e!d*oblorure .(sel marin) queJaar eaulr des (mies de Rod B1 Parag. L'eau des pniêeoOntlesè-aee-esttaioe quan- tité d'ammtaûaqne, -on moyenne 0.90 h 0.25. milligrammes, par litre. Comme, on, rencontre encore souvent Vidéequ'une-eau qui -«obtient de l'ammoniaque en pareil'e quantité est très suspeote d'être oonéaminée par des filtrations insalubres et partant»» propre b la oonsomma- tior, il faot remarquer, que l'ammoDiaque trouvée dans l'ean des pnits de Bol El Farag n'est point due è des infiltrations qui {mar- raient provenir de la surface on à l'aspiration de l'eau souterraine plus on moins oootaminée de la ville du .Caire, mai» est plutôt d'une ori- gine -géologiq». Il a été constaté qae l'ean' de pnits profonds contient Bonvent des quan- tités d'ammeniaqne erore beanoonp plus con- sidérables, même si ces puits sont orensés dans le" régions inhabitées, b l'abri de toute infiltra- tion paisible. Aussi, trouvons-nous des quan- tités. semblable» d'ammoniaque dans presque tou» les puits qui ont été forés jusqn'b présent en Egyp'e nonobstant qa'une grande partie d'entr'enx est très éloignés de toate habitation hnraaine. Cours de l'Association des Courtiers en Marchandises
Operations in Natal have been practically suspended in order to give the natives an opportunity of surrendering. {Reuter)
A recrudescence of the strike has taken place at Baku. The town is completely terrorised. The police have refused to do duty. A manager named Bibieibat has been murdered. Reuter

div.head:
MISTAKEN FOR TREPOFF.
GENERAL SHOT DEAD.

div.p: General Kozloff was shot dead whilst walk- ing in the park at Peterhof. He was mistaken for General Trepeff. The assassin has been arrested. He confesses himself to be a member of the revolutionary party. {Reuter)

div.head:
GREAT FIRE AT NIJNI-NOVGOROD
276 HOUSES DESTROYED.

div.p: A great fire has taken place at N'jni-Nov- gorod. 975 houses, inoluding several ware- houses, were destroyed in six hours. (Reuter)
The Council of the Empire has adopted the Bill of the Duma opening a credit of IS million rubles to aid the victims of the famine.

div.head:
CRUISE OF BRITISH FLEET.
ENTIRELY ABANDONED.

div.p: The official omise of the British Fleet has been entirely abandoned owing to Russia's attitude. (Reuter)
Major Dreyfus has been appointed to the 12th Battery of Artillery. General Picqnart has also received a command. (Reuter) '
The "Liberté" credits Dreyfus with the intention of bringing a civil notion against General Meroier. (Havas)

div.head: THE AFRICAN SOCIETY.
TRIBUTE TO LORD CROMER.
div.p: The Duke of Marlborough, in his presidential address at the annual meeting ot the African Society held at the Imperial Institute last week, pointed ont that Great Britain had made herself responsible for between 3,000,000 and 4,000,000 of the 11,000,000 square miles which Africa contained, and, in addition, there were Egypt and the Sudan, over which she had considerable contro'.He believed that the best results were more likely to be obtained if the Administration in England trusted with implicit confidence to the capacity and intelligence and knowledge of the man on the spot, and that under great administrators like Lord Cromer and Sir F. Lugard the interests and well-being of the natives would be well oared for. After an allusion to the great future which be thought was awaiting Nigeria, he commented with satisfaction on the increasing recognition on the part of the publié of the immense productive capacities of some of the African Crown Colonies, and expressed a hope that in the near future they would be able to compete successfully with South America in the English markets. Very often the views of colonial administrators in regard to the natives were not quite in harmony with those of sections of the people at home who had not had the opportunity of travelling abroad. Those of our countrymen who lived in South Africa knew the importance of maintaining at a high level the status and position of white men. Cape Colony had already recognized the importance of stimulating the trade relations between England and herself. He thought that Great Britain should continue her efforts to improve the status oi the native, to develop fully the latent resources of the Crown Colonies, and to strengthen her trade relations with the African self- governing colonies.

div.head: CEYLONESE PEARLS.
div.p: How much more treasured is the already precious pearl when you know something of its story : the story of a growing thing, bom in the blue depths of tropical seas, coveted by man, jealously guarded, energetically sought, and sold and sold again before it fulfils its present destiny of gleaming against a background of smooth, fair skin ! Over seven thousand miles away, where the great pearl banks of Ceylon stretch along the western coast, for ever hidden by the humid waters of the Indian Ocean, this gem is found. On either side, far into the hazy distance, lies a shin, niering line of sand, which, barren and deserted, quivers eternally under the scorching tropical sun. InYront the sapphire sea stretches on and on to where the blue dome above seems to mingle with it and melt away into space. In long heaving lines the great green waves roll in, crumbling into creamy surf as they pass the reef, and with a hollow thud spring into glistening spray upon the dazzling beach. Behind, like a miniature mountain range, are miles of heaped-up shells that yielded pearls to adorn the brows of dark-skinned beauties, who walked the earth before Christ lie hidden under these mounds. The air is heavy with the odor of decay. For three parts of the year this desolate coast simmers patiently on, with no inhabitants other than turtles and crabs innumerable. But February comes round and fi filing is proclaimed. As if by magio, the place springs into life; hots are run up, sheds built and stocked with food and other: necessaries—and unnecessariness, while traders" and fishermen, jugglers and beggars, buyers and usurers pour in from all parts. Next the fishing fleet arrives, and canoes and catamarans swam everywhere. The fleet numbers about one hundred boats, each carrying a crew of twelve men and two or three divers. The divers are mostly Tamils and Moormer, who, despite the marvelous endurance and pluck which they display in the execution of their calling, are terrified of shark--. To protect themselves against this ever-present danger they carry charms given them by recognized shark-binders, who receive a small Government fee and adozm oysters a day from each boat. The sea is infested by shark1', but, owing to the oonBtant noise and splashing, accidents are rare. The banks lie some eight miles out, and, everything being ready, the boats start out at midnight. Fishing commences at dawn, and continues till noon, when, at a signal, operations are stopped, and the fleet returns to unload. A sale is immediately held, the oysters being sold by the thousand, though small speculators endowed with a sporting spirit can purchase three for 2J., and take their chance. Consolation can always be Bought by eating the oysters should they turn up blank.

After each daily sale, the smaller buyers' open their shells at one; the big dealers saving labor b£ burying them in pits, where the fish Boon rots away. The shells -are then dropped into troughs, washed, and carefully examined, the barren ones being thrown out in heaps, and those with pearls put into a separate trough. After repeated washings the dirt and sand disappear, and the loose gems can be picked out. The water is then strained off, and the small seal pearls collected, after which the whole lot is sorted, weighed, and valued in the presence of Government officers. The pearls growing on the oyster itself are round, bright, smooth, and flawless, and command the highest price of all. Those found attached to the shell are not so valuable, for, however Shapely and lustrous, there is always one imperfect side which must be concealed in a ring or other setting. Tube actual diving is performed in much the same manner now as it was a thousand years sago. The Ceylonese diver uses no artificial aids, scorning even to fill his ears with cotton- wool acid oil. Ho stands on a heavy sinking- stone attached to a rope, which be bolds with one hand, grips a basket, fattened to a separate line, between his knees, and, simply taking a deep breath and, holding his nose with the spare hand, slips under feet first and goes to the bottom. > The water is usually from forty to fifty feet deep, and in the dim green light, with a brain- breaking pressure on his head, the man tears the clinging oysters from their bed and pushes them into his net basket till breath fails him, and he jerks the rope. He is pulled up at top speed, usually lounging to the bottom of the basket and letting go a yard or to under the surface, when he shoots up out of the water dear of boat and gear. As round as the net is emptied, down he goes again, and after scope twenty dives have a rest, while an her man takes bus place. Some divers oan stay under fji over two minutes, but the pressure causes them to bleed at the ears and nose, and none of them live long—3uch is part of the price of a pearl. A diver bringing up 3,000 oysters between sunrise and noon earns about fifteen shillings a day—the fishing usually lasting three weeks, by which time his eyes are so bloodshot that no white can be seen. In another month all traces of the bnsy fishing vanish, except for a aile or so of tainted air. But millions of fcavenger crabs now crawl up from the sea and fall upon the masses of putrefaction, and soon a desolate peace is restored. The crabs return to the dim depths which man invades at his life's peril for the costly gems that they pass by witbont heeding ; and the murmuring sea lisps secrets of its treasures to ears that cannot understand.

div.head: WILL THE POPE ACCEDE?
ANXIETY OF CATHOLIC FRANCE.
div.p: The Paris correspondent of the "Evening Standard'' writes

The Paris correspondent of the "Evening Standard'' writes There is no sort of ritual question in France; at least, not in the sense in which it excites public opinion in England, but there is a religious question of immense importance pending at this moment. It is none other than this. What I'm to be the decision 6f the Pope in the matter of Separation? Will he accept the situation and form the Associations Cultuelles, or will he absolutely ignore the new condition of things 1 Catholics are awaiting the decision of the Holy See with an ill- concealed anxiety. A disquieting rumor has been in circulation here that his Holiness has the intention of disregarding the new law. It is to be hoped that so melancholy a decision will not be arrived at in the interests of the Church itself. The danger of the situation lies in the fact that PiuB X. is surrounded by Cardinals, who are not always the correot interpreters of the feeling in Franca. In this respect the Pope appears to be as unfortunate as the Tsar, whose advisers take infinite care to conceal the truth. It is said that the Holy Father was entirely misled as to the real current of opinion in France on the subject of Separation, and that the final aot in the dispute between the Vatican and the Minister of Religions here came upon him with the foroe of a surprise. He was not aware that anti-olerioal feeling would be oarried to the length of separation. If this be true, it is apparent that the occu- pant of the Holy See is in bad hands. Nothing could be more lamentable at this junoture than an adverse decision on the subject of the new law. The country oalls aloud lof peaoe ; it will not do for the Pope to offer it a sword. Repudiation of the new organisations would result in plunging the Churoh of France into a oauldron of difficulty and disoord ; it might result, even, in civil war. I am not sure that the bishops and inferior clergy would unanimously follow the Pope ; indeed, it is to be supposed that sohism would immediately appear. But the numbers on the side of the hierarchy would be sufficient to create a great cleavage in public opinion.

div.head: PRIEST AND PLUTOCRAT.
div.p: The occasion would be taken advantage of by the Government to deli er a last blow at the clerical citadel. Such an opportunity of displaying zeal against the Church would be hailed with joy by the Radicals. It would re- open the old Church question and divert Socialist attention from the moneyed wealth of the country ; it would be an excellent piece of politicos. The Church, as the elections have proved, is no longer a very formidable power : she is merely the symbol of an exploded political doctrine ; hence, there is little danger in attacking her, and always a certain amount of vlorv in the eves of a materialistic peasantry.

On the other hand, to attack oapital, as the Socialists are doing at this present moment, is a proceeding of a very different order. It alarms the good Radioals, who oare, or profess to oare, little for the Church, and it has an awkward habit of reooiling upon the heads of the Government in the shape of a diminished national credit and a general "malaise" and commercial timidity. No ; mnch better attaok the priest than the man of money ; the latter has an awkward habit of hitting baok ! A day or two ago the Abbé Lemire, one of the most courageous as well as one of the most oharming deputies in the Chamber, in the oourse of an informal conversation in the oorridor, put his finger on one of the ills that affeot the Catholio body politic. It is the bad service rendered the party by its newspapers. One of the most violent, abusive, and sub- versive orgaps in Franoe has made itself the mouthpiece of Catholicism. It has reoeivcd more than one domioiliary visit from the polioe. Frankly, dear Catholio people, that is not the way to advanoe your oause. Suppress your evil- tongued newspapers, accept the laje as a "ohose faite," and the Church will prosper even in Republican and, apparently, sceptioal France.

div.head: JEWS RETURNING TO PALESTINE.
div.p: It is stated by a Jerusalem correspondent that Jews have been returning to the Holy Land in large numbers during the past few months.

Reoently about 5,000 Jewish immigrants from Russia and the Balkan S'ates landed at Jaffa. They will settle in the plain of Sharon, round the towns of Ramleh and Lydds, and in other Jewish colonies along the sea coast.

A few days ago some Jewish financiers made a trip to the region east of the Jordan, in the direction of Eerak. They saw the land, and were highly satisfied with its fertility acd the nature of its soil. They are willing to oolonise the district, but are rather suspicions of the neighbouring Bedouin tribe*, who are averse to any permanent settlement being effeoted in their midst.

It is believed that the Jews are in communi- cation with the Government on the subject, and should the latter give them sufficient gua- rantee of proteotion against the raids of their neighbours the sale of large traots will soon be completed.

It is a noteworthy faot that some of the most fertile districts of Palestine are possessed by Jewish colonists. The Jews are repossessing the land by degrees, and should this quick rate of possession oontinue, the whole country will in a few years belong entirely to them.

div.head: THE ABYSSINIA AGREEMENT.
div.p: FORMALLY INITIALLED IN LONDON.

The "Eoho de Paris" states that the agree- meet between Great Britain, France, end Italy on the subject of Abyssinia, which was formally initialed in London last Saturday, will be on the following lines. The railway as far as Addis Ababa will remain French, as provided in the concession granted to France by the Negus, and Italy will be permitted to build a railway connecting Eritrea and the Be nadir colony if she so desires. The status quo in Abyssinia will be preserved, the three Powers undertaking to uphold the present régime. The agreement will not obtain any secret danses. The "Petit Parisien" states that the agreement is particularly agreeable to King Edward, who recognizes in the facility with which the agreements have been come to the happy effect of the entente cordial and an additional proof of the excellent relations which exist between England, Italy, and France. So grati- field was he when Sir Edward Grey informed him of the happy issue of negotiations that King Edward promptly addressed telegrams to the King of Italy and President Fallières expressing his warm satisfaction. , Sir Edward Grey has also sent a filiations telegram to M. Bourgeois, Minister for Foreign Affairs. After stating that the agreement folly safsgnards the interests of the three nations, Sir Edward expresses the hope that it will be welcomed by the Emperor Menelik and become immediately effective.

div.head: COMMUNICATED TO GERMANY.
div.p: The semi-official "Norddentsohe Alleghenies Zeitnng" publishes a statement to the effect that Italy has confidentially communicated to the German Government the contents of the Abyssinia agreement. This step is the first obvions result of German action in the Moroooo question, which, it will be remembered, arose from the fact that France failed to communicate to Germany the contents of the English- French agreement concerning Moroooo. The matter is important, as it now appears that a certain diplomatic precedent has been estafc'ished whereby for the fattener every Great Power will have to «acquaint other countries, at least confidentially, with the nature of their separate arrangements with third parties, even where these are only countries of the third or fourth class. It is obvions that Italy agreed to It is obvions that Italy agreed to make the present communication, as being a member of the Triplioe, so that England and Franoe are Bpared what might by many people be regarded as a kind of humiliation.

div.head: FEVERISH RUSSIAN ARMY.
div.p: THE BACILLUS OF REVOLUTION MAKING HEADWAY.

It is stated that the men of the Viborg Regiment recently refused to obey an order to prepare to fire on a large body of Admiralty employees, whose attitude rendered the authorities uneasy. At Sevastopol large mass meeting of soldierly are held daily.

One of these meetings passed a resolution to support the working men in their struggle for better conditions of living. A building is in course of erection near the Palace of Peterhof to accommodate the armored motoroars, of which the authorities now possess a considerable number.

A court martial at Tifiis is trying the case of 37 men of the Mingrelian Regiment, who are oharged with having taken part in disturbances. One of the prisoners has escaped from hospital. The trial has caused a general strike in the town. Neither cabs nor trams are running, and the bakers,' butchers,' and grocers' shops are dosed. In ; everal parts of the town batteries of guns and qniok-firers have been posted, and the pickets have every- where been strengthened. The streets are, however, quiet. The strike was the result of an appeal which was made by the looal Socialist, revolutionary, and Social Democratic commit- tees, and is intended as a protest against the trial of the oase by oourt martial. No news- papers are appearing. The trial, which is in camera, will ocoopy several days.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement OF THE " Egyptian Gazette. "
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the ootton, ootton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics np to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the oopies of the offioial telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, eto., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt. For abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For further particulars apply to the Manager "Egyptian Gazette."

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
